text:
Why should you keep well
to the left as you approach a
right-hand bend?

options.A: To let faster traffic from behind overtake
options.B: To improve your view of the road
options.C: To be positioned safely if you skid
options.D: To overcome the effect of the road’s slope

explanation: To improve your view of the road. Keeping left on right-hand bends gives you a better view around the corner.

text:
You’ve just gone through
flood water. What should
you do to make sure your
brakes are working
properly?

options.A: Accelerate and keep to a high speed for a short time
options.B: Stop for at least an hour to allow them time to dry
options.C: Avoid using the brakes at all for a few miles
options.D: Go slowly while gently applying the brakes

explanation: Two seconds. The 'two-second rule' is the minimum safe following distance in good conditions.

text:
You're following a vehicle on a wet road. You stay a 
safe distance behind it. 
What should you do if a 
driver overtakes you and 
pulls into the gap you've 
left?

options.A: Drop back to regain a safe distance
options.B: Flash your headlights as a warning
options.C: Try to overtake safely as soon as you can
options.D: Stay close to the other vehicle until it moves on

explanation: Slow down. In icy conditions, reduce speed and drive very carefully as grip is severely reduced.

text:
You're travelling on the
motorway. How can you
lower the risk of a collision
when the vehicle behind is
following too closely?

options.A: Move onto the hard shoulder and stop
options.B: Switch on your hazard warning lights
options.C: Increase your distance from the vehicle in front

explanation: At least four seconds. In wet conditions, you should double the two-second rule to at least four seconds.

text:
You're following other 
vehicles in fog. You have 
your headlights on dipped beam. What else can you do to reduce the chances of 
being in a collision?

options.A: Keep up with the faster vehicles
options.B: Keep close to the vehicle in front
options.C: Keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front
options.D: Use main beam instead of dipped headlights

explanation: Leave a two-second gap. This gives you adequate time to react and stop if the vehicle ahead brakes suddenly.

text:
What should you do
when you're using a
contraflow system?

options.A: Choose an appropriate lane in good time
options.B: Switch lanes to make better progress
options.C: Increase speed to get through the contraflow more quickly
options.D: Follow other motorists closely to avoid long queues

explanation: Much greater. Icy conditions can increase stopping distance by up to 10 times normal distance.

text:
How can you avoid
wheelspin when you're
driving on an icy road?

options.A: Drive at a slow speed in the highest gear possible
options.B: Use the parking brake if the wheels start to slip
options.D: Drive in a low gear at all times

explanation: The road may be slippery. Leaves on the road become slippery when wet, reducing tire grip.

text:
What's the main cause of
skidding?

options.B: The driver

explanation: Increase your following distance. In rain, longer stopping distances mean you need more space.

text:
You're driving in freezing
conditions. What should you
do as you approach a sharp
bend?

options.B: Coast into the bend

explanation: Stay at the same steady speed. Maintaining constant speed is safest when overtaking on dual carriageways.

text:
You're about to start a journey in freezing weather.
What part of your vehicle should you clear of ice and snow?

options.B: The bumper

explanation: At least two seconds. The two-second rule is the minimum safe following distance in good conditions.

text:
What will help you to
move off on a snowy
surface?

options.B: Using the parking brake and footbrake together
options.C: Using a higher gear than normal

explanation: Before turning. Position yourself correctly before the turn, not during it when you need to focus on steering.

text:
What should you do
when you're driving in
snowy conditions?

options.B: Brake gently in plenty of time

explanation: Slow down. When you see hazard warning lines, reduce speed as they indicate potential danger ahead.

text:
What's the main benefit
of driving a four-wheel-drive
vehicle?

options.B: Improved passenger comfort

explanation: Four seconds. In wet conditions, double the two-second rule to at least four seconds.

text:
You're about to go down
a steep hill. What should
you do to control the speed
of your vehicle?

options.A: Select a low gear and avoid using the brakes
options.B: Select a high gear and use the brakes carefully
options.C: Select a high gear and use the brakes firmly
options.D: Select a low gear and use the brakes carefully

explanation: Reduce your speed. Bright sunlight can reduce visibility and mask hazards, so slow down.

text:
What should you do
when you park a car facing
downhill?

options.A: Turn the steering wheel towards the kerb
options.B: Turn the steering wheel away from the kerb
options.C: Park with two wheels on the kerb
options.D: Park close to the bumper of another car

explanation: At least doubled. Wet road surfaces significantly increase stopping distances.

text:
You're driving in a built-up area that has traffic-
calming measures. What should you do when you approach a road hump?

options.A: Wait for any pedestrians to cross
options.B: Move across to the left-hand side of the road
options.C: Check your mirror and slow down

explanation: At least four seconds. Double the normal gap in wet conditions due to increased stopping distances.

text:
On what type of road
surface may anti-lock brakes
be ineffective?

options.B: Smooth

explanation: The road ahead is slippery. Surface water makes roads slippery, especially dangerous in freezing conditions.

text:
You're driving a vehicle that has anti-lock brakes.
How should you apply the footbrake when you need to stop in an emergency?

options.B: Rapidly and firmly

explanation: At least ten times. Ice can increase stopping distances by up to 10 times compared to dry roads.

text: You're driving along a country road. You see this sign. What should you do after dealing safely with the hazard?

options.B: Switch on your hazard warning lights

explanation: Leave a longer gap. In fog, increase your following distance as you have less time to react.

text:
What would suggest
you're driving on an icy
road?

options.B: There's less tyre noise

explanation: Stay back until you can see clearly. Never overtake unless you have a clear, safe view ahead.

text:
You're driving along a
wet road. How can you tell if
your vehicle’s tyres are
losing their grip on the
surface?

options.A: The steering will feel very light
options.B: The engine will stall
options.C: The steering will feel very heavy

explanation: Allow the driver to pull away. In congestion, leaving space helps traffic flow more smoothly.

text:
In which conditions will your overall stopping 
distance increase?

options.B: In the rain

explanation: You'll be able to stop within the distance you can see. Safe speed means being able to stop in the visible distance.

text: You're driving on an open road in dry weather. What distance should you keep from the vehicle in front?

options.B: Two car lengths

explanation: At least two seconds. This is the minimum safe following distance on dry roads in good conditions.

text:
How should you use
anti-lock brakes when you
need to stop in an
emergency?

options.A: Apply the parking brake to reduce the stopping distance
options.B: Keep pumping the footbrake to prevent skidding
options.C: Brake normally but grip the steering wheel tightly
options.D: Brake promptly and firmly until you've stopped

explanation: Increase your following distance. In poor weather, you need more space to stop safely.

text:
What lights should you use when you're driving on a wet motorway and vehicles are throwing up surface 
spray?

options.B: Hazard warning lights

explanation: At least doubled. Wet roads significantly reduce tire grip, doubling stopping distances.

text:
What can result when
you travel for long distances
in neutral (known as
coasting)?

options.B: Easier steering

explanation: Reduction in control. Coasting reduces engine braking and control, especially when going downhill or in slippery conditions.

text:
What should you do
when you're overtaking a
motorcyclist on a windy
day?

options.B: Pass closely

explanation: Pass widely. Give motorcyclists extra room on windy days as gusts can push them off course.

text:
What does it mean if the Electronic Stability Control (ESC) indicator light comes on briefly while you’re 
driving?

options.A: The ESC system is switched off
options.B: The ESC system has activated
options.C: The ESC system has a fault
options.D: The ESC system is running a routine test

explanation: The ESC system has activated. A brief flash means the system is working to help stabilize the vehicle.
